The Mega Man games have always been interesting and fun to play. The ability to pick your own path through the game always makes the replay value go way up. In the first Mega Man X game the creators at Capcom upped the anti by adding 4 armor upgrades, heart tanks and a revised subtank system. What I took away from this game was how wonderful the play control is. X is very responsive and with the ability to cling and slide down walls and springboard off gives the player a lot of freedom of movement not found in the old NES games. I originally thought of the old NES Ninja Gaiden games when I first played it. Mega Man X and Super Metroid probably have the best overall play control of any games on the SNES and should be included in everyone's gaming library.

The game is a blast to play the rock music fits the atmosphere perfectly and the future Blue Bomber is a force to be reckoned with when he is fully upgraded. I liked the idea of using animals as bosses instead of just "Man". The environmental changes in the game are also very unique and add a new perspective on the game. The backgrounds and stage layouts are interesting and the bosses are fun. The learning curve is pretty quick and once you learn the dash technique you will be zipping through the game. I also liked the idea of being able to Power up your boss weapons into supercharged weapons once you have the X-buster upgrade.

All the mini bosses put up a decent fight as well. The challenge is about average, its not very difficult nor is it a cakewalk either. I liked how the creators had a stage like Armored Armadillo that let you fill up your subtanks quickly by killing the bats getting all the energy. I thought the Spider boss always put up a good fight and enjoyed every battle with it. Sigma is a very good villain, more fearsome than Dr. Wiley. Besides I was getting tired of fighting Dr. Wily anyway. The X-series games would get better but the first one is definitelyworth playing. I would rate this a 5 star game.

Mega Man X3 came out at the end of the SNES lifespan. The game just feels like it was rushed out the door. Several reviewers have commented on how uninspiring the music is in the game and they are right. In several stages the sound just seems flat and boring except the Vile battle. Also the game felt like it had too many upgrades, many of which seemed useless to me while playing the game. What is the point of having 6 capsules if you can only pick 4. I liked how they brought Vile back and that the game was more challenging than X2 but not really in a good way. I loved fighting all 3 of the semi villains Bit, Bite and the other guy in X2 I thought that added a lot to the story and was fun. you get none of that enjoyment from X3 no backstory on the mini bosses. You do get to play as Zero in this game but I did not find him very easy to use or very practical to use in the game, he is much better in MMX4

Also the one major inconvenience I found in the game was there was no enemy similar to the bats in MMX that would always drop energy pellets or capsules where you could quickly fill up your subtanks. Or the water stage in MMX2 where you could quickly suck up 9 energy capsules right away to fill your tanks in seconds. Once you get to the final stages of X3 you will need every drop of those subtanks to deal with the cheap attacks from Vile and Sigma and it takes forever to fill the tanks back up. I also felt like the supercharged Boss weapons you get were weak or useless not very handy at all in this game compared to MMX1 or X2.

Mega Man games are held to a higher standard because they have been so good for so long. Even though this only the 3rd game in the X series both X1 and X2 were great games with a high replay value. After finally completing this game I had no real desire to play it again. As with all Mega Man games the play control is very good and you can dash up in this game, but besides that new feature this game is nothing towrite home about. I felt the game was just missing that fun element that the other 2 X games had. I have not played the Playstation version of the game but I hope it is much improved over this version. Final verdict its an average game 3 stars at best.

Also the GBA game slot likes to scratch pieces of plastic off of cartridges inserted into it (thanks to that metal piece you can see in the thumbnail) but I have many GBA's that I use over the DS for playing gba games, so that's not too big of a deal, but something to remember.

Overall, other then the cheap screwdrivers, most my issues with it can be traced back to me making various rookie mistakes that I feel I wouldn't make a second time and even with those issues/my inexperience with swapping shells, I've managed to get the system back together with a better hinge inside of it, and in perfect working order. I would recommend, especially if you either a. have experience taking apart electronics, or b. have a spare ds lite with a broken hinge or buttons and don't mind learning how to take one apart. Also one last thing, I used ifixit's guide on taking apart a ds lite over the guide that a sheet of paper links you to with the product.

I always considered myself more of action/adventure and fantasy fan. You play as Commander Shepard (either male of female) as you go through becoming a commander, commanding your own ship, discovering different worlds and planets all around the galaxy, building relationships with members of different races, you make decisions that have consequences, all of that as you prepare your self to fight and survive the eminent attack of an alien race called the Reapers.

The series made me appreciate Sci-Fi and I started eagerly watching Sci Fi series such as Battlestar Galactica, Stargate and I am about to start watching Star Trek. With the constant saturation of superheroes in today’s culture, it’s fairly surprising how almost none of the overall appeal associated with them has translated well into the video game market over the past several years.  Aside from 2004’s Spider-Man 2 and a handful of other exceptions, practically every superhero video game released in conjunction with its respective film has ranged from subpar to downright pitiful in overall quality. This is exactly why the Batman Arkham series is so fresh and invigorating. I heavily enjoyed playing all three Arkham games prior to this installment, including the somewhat despised Arkham Origins game, because I found their stories immersive and their combat simplistic, yet intuitive and exciting.  I’ve never been a big fan of stealth sequences due to their overly simple and repetitive design – in the Call of Duty campaigns they’re serviceable enough because of their brevity – but in these games, they’re engaging and strategical, and allow the player to approach them in a variety of ways.  I was really looking forward to how Arkham Knight would cultivate these superb elements of the previous games while integrating the much-touted Batmobile, but unfortunately the game ended up disappointing me, both in its story as well as its overreliance on the Batmobile during the main story missions.  The opening of this game is very avant-garde as the player witnesses the Joker’s corpse being incinerated while old-fashioned music is audible in the background. The first gameplay sequence actually has the player take control of a police officer during Scarecrow’s initial hallucinogenic gas attack in a diner. These two events came across as unexpected to me, and gave me hope that the remainder of the story would continue to catch me off guard.  However, most of the story, particularly how the writers handled the villains in this game, proves to be quite problematic, as I will discuss in more detail in my spoiler section. The first handful of hours of the game provide a strong enough launchpad—albeit a bit too exposition-heavy—for the plot to propel forward.  The Scarecrow has publicly threatened the citizenry of Gotham, which in turn almost entirely evacuates itself from the city, and Batman must team up with Gordon in order to take him down. While the Scarecrow character here appears more menacing than he did in Arkham Asylum, he takes a backseat for almost the entire game and isn’t prominently featured until the final act.  Instead, much of the game’s narrative focus is on uncovering the secret identity of the mysterious Arkham Knight, an “original” character who was purportedly created specifically for this game. The writers completely mishandled this character throughout the story, and squander any opportunity of making him intriguing or threatening towards Batman by blatantly foreshadowing far too much information to the audience, so much so that I’d reckon most players will be apathetic or disappointed after discovering the Arkham Knight’s true identity.  The ending to Arkham City acted as an excellent bookend to the Arkham trilogy prior to this game, and ultimately, the story here feels superfluous and unneeded, and nothing in it really justifies its own existence besides the publishers simply wanting to make another Arkham game.  Thankfully, the core gameplay mechanics are as solid as ever.  Hand-to-hand combat is unaltered from the previous games, as it should be.  The combat mechanics are virtually flawless, so just because it doesn’t break any new ground doesn’t warrant fan complaints about there being a “lack of innovation,” an issue that’s arisen more and more frequently in recent years with the Call of Duty and Assassin’s Creed franchises. Change for the sake of change (or broader market appeal) is inherently bad and generally doesn’t accomplish much except for the alienation of the core fan base. For what it’s worth, I’ll mention that twonew enemies have been added during the combat sequences to spice things up a bit, the first of which is an enemy who attempts to tackle Batman, and the second one being an electrically-armored foe who is temporarily invulnerable to Batman’s attacks. Aside from this, though, there’s nothing more to say about these sequences besides the fact that they’re as fluid, free-flowing, and hard-hitting as they’ve ever been in this franchise.  The stealth sequences/predatory roams now take place in locales that are for the most part more open-ended and larger than those that came before, thus allowing the player more freedom to approach them. The most notable addition is the ability to perform what the game refers to as “multi fear takedowns,” which allow you to easily surprise and dispatch of several enemies in a rapid succession without taking any damage. While these maneuvers are enjoyable enough to execute, they make the act of being stealthy a tad bit too easy. Regardless, these stealth encounters are still the best I’ve ever played before in a video game.  Where the game falters in overall enjoyment is in the segments in which the player is forced to use the Batmobile for extended periods of time.  The Batmobile/Bat-Tank is divided into two separate modes, the first of which is the act of simply driving around Gotham. The default control scheme for the vehicle is cumbersome and counterintuitive to every driving game you’ve ever played prior to this. Thankfully, there’s an option to resort to using a secondary, more recognizable setup for the vehicle, but the catch is that that option isn’t explicitly presented in the options menu. So while this problem is technically fixable, I’d wager that many players still be stuck using the default scheme just based upon how muddled the process of altering it is.  Assuming you actually get around to using the secondary scheme, driving around the city can be quite enjoyable, but it still leaves a bit to be desired.  Many of the streets in Gotham feel a bit too narrow for the Batmobile, so you’ll often collide against the side of buildings whenever you turn onto another street, and there are few streets that allow the Batmobile to accelerate to its top speed for more than a couple of seconds.  Gliding around the city and using your grappling hook is still a far more preferable method to traverse the urban landscape, especially since Batman can now select his next grappling target while still being reeled in on his hook, allowing for a more fast-paced, instantaneous travel experience. While I appreciate how this addition makes traveling more efficient, it takes away a lot of the skill required to hone the grappling hook in Arkham City, where accuracy and timing were more predominant.  The vehicle’s other mode transforms it into a tank that you use to engage unmanned, remote-controlled drones.  Most of these encounters boil down to shooting at enemy drones while constantly dodging their line of fire by quickly thrusting left or right. Continually obliterating these enemy drones progressively builds up a meter in the corner of the screen, which, once filled, allows your tank to unleash a barrage of missiles upon your enemies. Now, there’s nothing inherently wrong or broken with these tank battles, but they lack any real opportunities to approach them in different ways like the aforementioned sequences, both of which have had three games to be refined to perfection. Many of its sections in the game require you to sneak around behind a beefed-up tank and hit it in its weak spot, drive away, and then repeat the same attack. I firmly believe that the Batmobile should've been relegated as a transportation option only, or perhaps having side missions devoted to it, but certainly not mandatory for around 40% of main story missions. If the developers so desperately wanted it to be included in the primary missions, then those missions should’ve been open-ended to the point whereplayer can complete them in several different ways.  The other major issue I have with this game in terms of its game design is the absence of any substantial boss fights. Granted, there is one exception that takes place around halfway through the game, where Batman fights alongside Robin to defeat a formidable, muscle-bound African-American boxer. The fight sequence is one of the few highlights of the game because it takes advantage of the best aspects of the series. However, as good as the fight is, it doesn’t suffice when it lasts for ten minutes at most and it takes roughly 15 hours to complete the game. Almost every other boss fight in the game is vehicular, involving the same repetitive techniques you employ during each tank fight. This problem wouldn’t upset me so much if the boss fights in the previous games hadn’t been so excellent.  The game even rubs salt in the wound by featuring Deathstroke, with whom Batman had engaged in a momentous clash in Arkham Origins, only to have him fight Batman in yet another generic tank battle before getting his lights punched out instantly as soon as he steps foot outside his tank.  There are a bevy of side missions at your disposal, most of which I haven’t bothered to delve into just yet. I attempted to complete a few Riddler challenges, which, to my knowledge, only consist of driving the Batmobile around underground racetracks, which grew tiresome very quickly. Perhaps I’ll return to complete all of the side activities eventually, but from what I’ve experienced of them so far, they’re comparable to those featured in Arkham City.  The audiovisual presentation in this game is phenomenal on all fronts.  The Arkham games have always excelled in this department, but this game outclasses them by having better lighting, smoother animations, and far more activity occurring on screen at once.  This game joins, and even surpasses in some aspects, the ranks of The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt and Far Cry 4 as being one of the best-looking games ever made.  In terms of sound, everything you hear during gameplay is fine, and the voice acting for the most part is good. I was disappointed in the Arkham Knight’s voice because it made him appear less intelligent and too whiney, and Kevin Conroy at times sounds uninspired during certain scenes, lacking inflection and conviction in his voice.  I know that a lot of people feel nothing but contempt for Arkham Origins, but for me, this is by far the worst game of this now four-part series. While the game is gorgeous to behold, and its hand-to-hand and predatory segments are mechanically flawless, many of the villains and ideas in the story are mishandled, the tank combat is lackluster, and there are hardly any worthwhile boss encounters.  Don’t get me wrong, this is still a solid enough game, (although I wouldn’t recommend paying full price for it) but it’s ultimately just extremely disappointing to me as a follow-up to Arkham City, which I still consider to be one of the best games I’ve ever played.

column13: Buy at your own risk. Sometimes you win, sometimes you lose!
column14:
I've had this mouse for about 4 months now and I have used it everyday for several hours at a time. I liked a lot of things about this mouse but it has a few flaws/defects that have caused me to replace this mouse with a more expensive brand gaming mouse. I've used this mouse for mostly gaming and internet browsing. The types of games I've played are FPS's, strategy, MMO and RPG type games.

First, I'd like to go over a few things that I liked about the mouse. It feels great, even though I have smallish hands. The two side buttons are crisp and easy to press. It slides smoothly on my mouse pad. I have not had any issues with phantom clicks or releases. The lights on the mouse are pretty subtle compared to some other brands, which is nice. It's a pretty good deal for the price.

The "deal breaking" issue for me is that my mouse came with a defective mouse wheel. The mouse wheel is hard to spin because it rubs up against the left side of the wheel housing. As you can see in my picture, the mouse wheel is not centered in the wheel housing. It came out of the box this way. Also, the middle mouse button sometimes does not work and I have to spin the mouse wheel one or two full rotations before it will work. For me, this defect makes this mouse very difficult to use for gaming and browsing the web. I use the mouse wheel a lot for key binds and camera control (depending on the game) and I have tried to power though it, change my gameplay style to work around the defect. In the end, it was just not working out and I purchased another brand/type of mouse to match my gaming preferences.

Another issue I've had is the optic sensor does not seem to be one of quality. I've had a lot of issues with precision. When I try to move my mouse a tiny amount, the pointer jumps all over the place. This is not an issue of too much mouse sensitivity. When I move the mouse pointer slowly straight down, the pointer is jumping wildly to the left and right.For example, some video players have very tiny video controls, and I have a hard time turning down the volume or pausing /playing the video due to the pointer jumping around.

To be honest if it weren't for the mouse wheel issue, I would have given this product four stars. I feel like when you buy a cheaper product like this, you're kinda rolling the dice on what you will get. Sometimes you luck out and get a great product with no defects and you get your moneys worth. Other times, like with what happened to me, you get a lemon. It's up to you to decide if it is worth your time and money to gamble on the quality this product. Thank you for reading!

You'd be hard-pressed to find someone that doesn't know America's Favorite Board Game. It's a timeless classic for families that like to gather around and pull out a physical non-electronic game to play with each other. Should you decide to play Monopoly on a video game device, however, various companies have been willing to oblige for decades now, as there still continue to be video game versions of the board games to this very day. This Game Boy Color cartridge is one of those many versions released over time.

This particular take on Monopoly is actually the same thing as the original Game Boy version of Monopoly, which in itself was a handheld port of the conversion on the NES. This time, Monopoly on the go has its own brand of color, but that's really the only difference, which is nice and actually underwhelming at the same time. I've played the NES version of Monopoly, and after having experienced this portable counterpart, I realized that there are actually several sound effects and jingles missing. No jingle plays when accessing a menu or hitting a Chance/Community Chest card, and the house-building is practically devoid of anything eventful-sounding.

That isn't to say this isn't fun. After all, this is Monopoly we're talking about, and these oldschool takes on the game do function like Monopoly should; everything gameplay-wise is there and accounted for. You buy properties, build houses, go around the board and land on spaces, etc; it's indeed Monopoly as anyone that's played the game knows it. That is, unless you've always played with House Rules, which this game lacks; you're going to have to auction off properties you don't want to buy, and there's no money pot for Free Parking. Other than that, if you've had fun with playing the actual board game, you'll have fun with this. It's the same game as the real thing, just squeezed into a small cartridge, which is definitely great for not having to keep track of paper play money. You can even play with friends and family simply by sharing your Game Boy!ven play with friends and family simply by sharing your Game Boy!

column14: Technically if I could rate this a little under 4 stars I probably would because I feel that would better represent my review, but I'll round up for now mainly because I sought out my own solution instead of contacting the seller about the issue I had with the product. It's a fairly minor issue, so I would have felt bad asking them to send a new one because of it.  For those who are thinking of purchasing this item, this product is a nice, light-weight wooden board with approximately 2" holes bored into it deep enough for your Amiibo's to fit into comfortably. They do wiggle ever so slightly, but I feel they fit well enough where they aren't likely to fall out, but aren't so tightly squeezed in that you could scratch the bases of your Amiibos in order to pull them out. The base is then throughly coated in a matte black paint, and then has a thicker red/green/blue paint blotches added on which is my (and probably everyone else's) favorite part. It also comes with 4 felt pads you can place on the bottom of the stand so that it doesn't scratch up the table, which is a very nice thought from the seller. It's a pretty nice stand overall though, and if you want to showcase off your Splatoon Amiibos then this is something worth considering.  With all of that being said, there was 1 main issue that I had with this product that may not bother others as much as it did me (I'm just a stickler for details). After the 2" diameter holes are bored into the stand, it doesn't seem like the hole was sanded down at all, leaving a rough finish inside of the hole, most notably at the very bottom of the holes (the sides weren't as bad on mine). After paying an arm and a leg for my Amiibo, I didn't want the bases to get scratched up, so I searched around for something to place at the bottom of the base that would protect them from the rough finish, and I came across this: [[ASIN:B00HZ9YWWG Shepherd Hardware 9971 2-Inch Surface Grip Adhesive Non Slip Pads, 8-Pack]]  This self-adhesive, anti-skid pads are add-on items that cost less than $2, and they are thin enough so they didn't push my Amiibo out of the stand, but added protective padding to the base of the holes. The pads fit in without a problem and had barely any distance between the edge of the pads and the inner hole's walls. The only down side is you only need 3 of the 8 that it comes with, but for less than $2, I'm not going to gripe much about the extra 5 pads that I didn't necessarily need.  While it's possible my order was a rare case that had a missed step in production, others may not need the adhesive pads, but if anyone does happen to have this issue, I wanted to at least give the solution that I found. I wish I could add photos to this, but unfortunately I already put the pads on the base of the stand. Anyways, I hope this helped those who read my lengthy review, but happy buying all!  ---------------------------------------------[Updated 8/31/15]-------------------------------------------  4 Star to 5 Star Review  I just received the felt patches in the mail today, and was pleasantly surprised to see them. Each color matches the different colors of the Inkling boy/girl/squid, and while they aren't visible when the Amiibo are in the holder itself, it shows their attention to detail (since they sent 3 separate colors instead of 3 felt patches of the same color) and it provides the scratch protection that I had concerns about originally.To Toyplicity, thank you for listening to your customers' concerns, and to everyone else, happy buying!

column14:
It pains me to write a review that doesn't give this headset a full five stars.

I received this item from Amazon just yesterday and spent the majority of an evening setting it up and adjusting any/all settings.I will say these headphones are well packaged and you can see the quality of the product/company. It felt like a real studio headset when picking it up for the first time and placing them on my head. The earphones are very comfortable and felt amazing to my ears. Setting up the unit was pretty easy (Just make sure you have the mute cord closer to your body). I immediately booted up Spotify to hear some tunes and I was very impressed with the clarity of this set... until... a slow popping noise became apparent. It was in my left ear and it seemed to be on a loop every 10 seconds or so. I googled this and looked for potential solutions and troubleshooted everything possible. I resorted to switching out sound cards (SB Titanium to Sound Blaster Z) which seemed to work. If I didn't have an extra sound card to try out, I would've been out of luck. (Strike 1)

With the electric clicking now gone, I resumed listening to all types of music. I wanted to hear a variety of genres to ensure I heard exactly what this headset had to offer. Although it wasn't a punchy as my G35's, they sounded much better and clearer than previous headsets. Being a gamer I then exposed this headset to the true test... Battlefield 4. Although the sound seemed very clear, this is where the headphones started to dwindle for me. I immediately plugged in my Logitech's to get a real life comparison of the difference between the two and I was startled. My G35's blew the Astro's away because of the boom factor for me. Not good... (Strike 2)

After playing a game or two, I decided to check out how the mic sounded with the A40's. I cannot tell you how lousy and tough it was to actually get them to work with Teamspeak. I had a brother, who owns his own TS server, assisting and he could've figure it out either. Without the mic, the headset was literally useless to me. I spent at least two hours trying to configure, reconfigure and google any possible fixes and ended up with nothing. (Strike 3)

Just when I got ready to turn my computer off... the electric click came back... contacted Amazon and opened a return ticket. I'll be sticking with my Logitech g35's. The a40's look amazing and sound pretty darn good, but for a price tag of $250 I was expecting a LOT more.

column13: Lunar: A updated trip down memory lane
column14:
The Setup (Overview):

A ancient disaster forced the abandonment of the the world's sister planet, The Silver Star. Seeking to save at least some of the population of the doomed planet, the goddess Althenia used her powers to bring the survivors to a new world where she used the last of her energy to transform the barren wasteland into a vibrant world where the sins of the past could be avoided. To ensure that peace reigned four beings, known as dragons, were given power over the forces of light, dark, fire and water.

Their avatar in this world was known as the Dragon Master. She then retired to the goddess tower where she sleeps until she is needed again. Whenever the balance of the world was threatened brave men and women would set out to complete the dragons trials and earn the power necessary to deal with the threat. This cycle continued for thousands of years until the last Dragon Master, Dyne, perished under mysterious circumstances. The evil that threatened the world was defeated, but for the first time in memory there was no Dragon Master to maintain balance in the world. The world was left to deal with it's problems on it's own. The dragons were silent. It didn't take long for some to forget what the silent, silver reminder in the sky warned against.

The Story(Some Story Details):

The story begins in the remote town of Burg, fifteen years after the death of Dragon Master Dyne. An ancient evil has begun to stir on what as known as the frontier, a barren land that is beyond the reach of the Goddesses Althena's power. While rumors swirl of the return of the “Magic Emperor”, a title associated with anyone who unites the monsters of the frontier, they are just rumors without any proof. While some of these stories have reached the remote island town of Burg, they are far away and more the problem of the magic guild which is located on the main land.

More popular are the stories of the legendaryDragon Master Dyne and his companions. Though most consider the stories to be a exaggeration of actual events, this doesn't matter to a young man by the name of Alex. He dreams of becoming the next Dragon Master and going on grand adventures to thwart evil where ever it may be. One day he gets his chance when exploring the nearby White Dragon Cave. In a flash of light the White Dragon appears and grants Alex the Dragon Ring, the first relic needed on the journey to become the Dragon Master.

Soon Alex sets out on a journey to find the remaining Dragons and assume the role of Dragon Master. With him are his childhood friends ,Ramus, Luna, and his flying cat Nall. Their first stop is the magic guild, where they soon find that their journey might not be as simple as they thought...

Conclusion(My Overall Opinion on the Story):
I played this game when it first came out years ago. It was one of my favorite RPG's of the time and even though the graphics have been updated and a few things removed, like that awesome original opening song, it's still the engaging story I played all those years ago. There are several new scenes that have been added to flesh out the story and there are various game play tweaks that make the game a little more streamlined for modern times. In this version you can save anywhere, the graphics have been updated, the combat system has been streamlined with tactics that can be customized and probably a few more features that I am missing.

The only downside to this game is that the combat hasn't aged that well. The combat is your standard turn based fair where you select an attack for each character and then they do said attack and then the enemy takes it's turn and does the same. While I don't like overly complicated battle systems, there isn't much need to think about tactics in this game, except for a couple of battles. This is helped a little by the fact enemies are visible on the map and, can occasionally, be avoided but there is still a lot of battles where it boils down to pick your area spell of choice and repeat two or three times till the battle is over and then repeat.

The good thing though is that the story and the characters hold up even though it is your standard boy saves the world and gets the girl story. So if your looking for a classic rpg to sink some time into give this one a shot. m.a.c

column6: SteelSeries Siberia P300 Comfortable Gaming Headset for PlayStation 4, PlayStation 3
column14:
The P300 is a solid performer for the money. I have some other very nice headphones that I use, namely the Turtle Beach XP510, and the Polk 4-Shot. Sound-wise, I don't think the P300 quite measures up. For one thing, with the volume cranked all the way up, it's only moderately loud. The sound dynamics overall, don't sound quite as good as the XP510 or 4-Shot, but they are less expensive headphones, so that is to be expected.

Using them with the PS4 works like a charm, and couldn't be simpler. Just plug them into the controller, the PS4 immediately recognizes them, and reconfigures the system to output to the headphones and also take mic audio from them as well. Very nice!

They like to promote the P300 Comfort factor. To me they are overselling that a bit. Yes, they are comfortable, but really not any more so than other quality headphones.

Overall the P300's are nice, quality headphones at a fair price. If you spend more, you will notice a difference in sound, but they sound perfectly fine. About the only thing I have misgivings about with the P300 is the overall build quality. When you hold the headphones, and examine them, it is quickly apparent that you are holding a pretty cheaply made, flimsy, insubstantial piece of plastic, so I definitely have some concerns about them holding up to hard use. If you take care of them though... they should be fine. Give em a try! You could do a lot worse.

I'm a big fan of the InFamous franchise. I've platinumed every single game, including Festival of blood, and I felt the previous games had something fairly unique to offer.

This game, however, does not. If you're expecting time traveling future versions of yourself, a wide array of combat mechanics, or a more nuanced karma system, this game will not satisfy you. The story is more along the lines of an X-Men knock off, the main character is a smart mouthed, flashy character with powers that basically equate to flashy lights, fog machine, and holograms, and he does funky graffiti. The side quest vary little, and repeat far too often. The game is fairly quick to complete, and I 100 percented my first playthrough in about 14 hours.

So why does it have 4 stars? Well, even though it doesn't quite have the level of depth the prior games have, this game was FUN! Zipping around the city at high speeds leaving a streak of light behind you, attacking enemies with smoke bombs, and bombarding goons with video projections is good fun. The game handles well, and utilizes the touch pad, motion controls, and the speaker on the controller quite well. It's a great game to test the new PS4 hardware on. The game also looks beautiful, and it fully showcases what the PS4 is capable of from a graphical standpoint as well.

Overall, this game feels like a summer blockbuster. Flashy and a lot of fun, but don't expect a ton of depth or rich narrative.

In my many years away from computer games, I'd somehow missed the rise of the Call of Duty series. A victim of Amazon's "Prime Day", I dutifully bought a copy of Call of Duty: Advanced Warfare when it appeared to be really cheap. The series has a reputation for having short single-player campaigns, but at half-price, I figured I could resell the disk if I didn't enjoy the multiplayer. (I expect not to play the multi-player game as I'd probably get slaughtered, and as someone who frequently gets interrupted in the middle of a game, I'd probably annoy all the other players by having to bail in the middle of a session)

I will say that I'm impressed. Much like Killzone 3, it's a surprisingly fun and linear first person shooter. But the difficulty setting (especially at "easy") is such that even I could play it through. What's particularly fun is that much as you could imagine it would be, you don't have to kill every enemy while progressing through a level to proceed. The game will proceed anyway if you simply charge forward. In the case of several of the set pieces, the game runs as though it were a Disneyland ride, rolling along at a breakneck pace while you do your best to nail as many enemies as possible, dodge obstacles, or simply keep up.

And just as with the Uncharted series or Killzone, you're never alone: you always have an NPC to guide you. This serves two purposes: in many cases, the NPC's there to tell you where you go. Secondly, the NPC serves as a marker, following you in case of assault, and even occasionally giving you a chance to assist. Unlike certain other games, the NPCs never nag at you, and only occasionally give you orders.

The story is thin, an excuseveneer to have fun. But boy, not having played one of these before, they're incredibly fun. Each segment of the single player campaign is unique, with set pieces that are never repeated in others. Whether it's night vision goggles, mute charges, or some new high tech warfare gadget, you're never given a chance to get sick and tired of the "oh wow" high tech special effects. The price of this of course, is player agency: you get one chance to drive the giant robot, one chance to drive a tank, one chance to drive the hoverbike, but you will never find one to hop on and use where the game designers have not placed it front and center (and an unavoidable part of the story). Nevertheless, when you do get the chance, you'll get a grin on your face and enjoy the heck out of it, because the entire set-piece is designed around the capabilities of your new toy. If this is part of the formula of the Call of Duty series, I can see why people line up for a chance to throw $60 every year to take part in the franchise: it's a heck of a lot more fun than most movies.

Technically, the game's a masterpiece as well. There's slight stuttering in scenes where you're in close quarters with your comrades, but never in combat. Once you're in combat, the game runs (on my PS4 at least) at a full 60fps, and looks gorgeous. The cut-scenes look like they're from a high-budget Hollywood action movie, and the in-game graphics aren't a lot worse. The set pieces have a few annoying QTEs, but no worse than any of the Uncharted games.

I will admit that I bought Wolfenstein: The New Order at half the price I paid for this, but even on the easiest difficulty level I'd get stuck. By contrast, Call of Duty was compellingly playable, had a much lighter story, and I never cared that I didn't find a single piece of Intel that was supposedly scattered throughout the levels of the single-player game: I got too engrossed and caught up in the situation presented, and never gave a thought to rooting around for hidden rewards when I could be off in another fire-fight with my squad-mates.

That speaks volumes as to how playable and how much fun the latest Call of Duty installment is. Wolfenstein, by the way, got much better reviews (and is a dedicated single player game to boot), but I suspect you'd have to be much more jaded (and competent) a FPS player than I am to pass up Call of Duty over the Wolfenstein series.

I planned to purchase a PS4 and wait for Halo 5 to buy the Xbox. After being won over by Titanfall previews I decided to get this bundle instead. I'll start with the game, then the console and how it compares to my PS4 that I just bought:

Titanfall: A fun new concept for an online shooter which bypasses a tradition campaign to focus on the multiplayer only combat. The servers were never an issue for me (compared to Destiny, a Bungie loot grindfest with pretty graphics and a lobotomized story) and the graphics were good enough. It was fun for a while but eventually lost my interest due to the lack of story.

Xbox One: This is a fantastic home theatre PC that can also play games! The kinetic is definitely worthwhile and allows for hands-free Hulu and Netflix watching. I am a longtime Halo fan and look forward to Halo 5 on this next gen console. The controller is a definite improvement over the Xbox 360. Microsoft is continually improving the Xbox OS and it will certainly see changes over the next few years that will only make it better (DirectX 12, cross platform gaming).

Compared to PS4: Now that I own both consoles the difference is very clear. The PS4 has a better controller (more innovative features like the trackpad and built-in 3.5mm audio jack), far more powerful GPU (1152 stream processors vs Xbox 768, 6 more asymmetric compute units, 32 vs 16 ROPs, GDDR5 vs DDR3 RAM), smaller package with built in power supply. Why did Microsoft go with such a large form factor and not put in power brick inside the case? Ultimately these are both GAMING consoles, and if you prefer gaming for the PS4. I'll still dust of the Xbox One for the exclusives like Quantum Break and Halo 5.

Xbox, why you bring so small a GPU and big power brick to console party?

With the constant saturation of superheroes in today’s culture, it’s fairly surprising how almost none of the overall appeal associated with them has translated well into the video game market over the past several years.  Aside from 2004’s Spider-Man 2 and a handful of other exceptions, practically every superhero video game released in conjunction with its respective film has ranged from subpar to downright pitiful in overall quality. This is exactly why the Batman Arkham series is so fresh and invigorating. I heavily enjoyed playing all three Arkham games prior to this installment, including the somewhat despised Arkham Origins game, because I found their stories immersive and their combat simplistic, yet intuitive and exciting.  I’ve never been a big fan of stealth sequences due to their overly simple and repetitive design – in the Call of Duty campaigns they’re serviceable enough because of their brevity – but in these games, they’re engaging and strategical, and allow the player to approach them in a variety of ways.  I was really looking forward to how Arkham Knight would cultivate these superb elements of the previous games while integrating the much-touted Batmobile, but unfortunately the game ended up disappointing me, both in its story as well as its overreliance on the Batmobile during the main story missions.  The opening of this game is very avant-garde as the player witnesses the Joker’s corpse being incinerated while old-fashioned music is audible in the background. The first gameplay sequence actually has the player take control of a police officer during Scarecrow’s initial hallucinogenic gas attack in a diner. These two events came across as unexpected to me, and gave me hope that the remainder of the story would continue to catch me off guard.  However, most of the story, particularly how the writers handled the villains in this game, proves to be quite problematic, as I will discuss in more detail in my spoiler section. The first handful of hours of the game provide a strong enough launchpad—albeit a bit too exposition-heavy—for the plot to propel forward.  The Scarecrow has publicly threatened the citizenry of Gotham, which in turn almost entirely evacuates itself from the city, and Batman must team up with Gordon in order to take him down. While the Scarecrow character here appears more menacing than he did in Arkham Asylum, he takes a backseat for almost the entire game and isn’t prominently featured until the final act.  Instead, much of the game’s narrative focus is on uncovering the secret identity of the mysterious Arkham Knight, an “original” character who was purportedly created specifically for this game. The writers completely mishandled this character throughout the story, and squander any opportunity of making him intriguing or threatening towards Batman by blatantly foreshadowing far too much information to the audience, so much so that I’d reckon most players will be apathetic or disappointed after discovering the Arkham Knight’s true identity.  The ending to Arkham City acted as an excellent bookend to the Arkham trilogy prior to this game, and ultimately, the story here feels superfluous and unneeded, and nothing in it really justifies its own existence besides the publishers simply wanting to make another Arkham game.  Thankfully, the core gameplay mechanics are as solid as ever.  Hand-to-hand combat is unaltered from the previous games, as it should be.  The combat mechanics are virtually flawless, so just because it doesn’t break any new ground doesn’t warrant fan complaints about there being a “lack of innovation,” an issue that’s arisen more and more frequently in recent years with the Call of Duty and Assassin’s Creed franchises. Change for the sake of change (or broader market appeal) is inherently bad and generally doesn’t accomplish much except for the alienation of the core fan base. For what it’s worth, I’ll mention that twonew enemies have been added during the combat sequences to spice things up a bit, the first of which is an enemy who attempts to tackle Batman, and the second one being an electrically-armored foe who is temporarily invulnerable to Batman’s attacks. Aside from this, though, there’s nothing more to say about these sequences besides the fact that they’re as fluid, free-flowing, and hard-hitting as they’ve ever been in this franchise.  The stealth sequences/predatory roams now take place in locales that are for the most part more open-ended and larger than those that came before, thus allowing the player more freedom to approach them. The most notable addition is the ability to perform what the game refers to as “multi fear takedowns,” which allow you to easily surprise and dispatch of several enemies in a rapid succession without taking any damage. While these maneuvers are enjoyable enough to execute, they make the act of being stealthy a tad bit too easy. Regardless, these stealth encounters are still the best I’ve ever played before in a video game.  Where the game falters in overall enjoyment is in the segments in which the player is forced to use the Batmobile for extended periods of time.  The Batmobile/Bat-Tank is divided into two separate modes, the first of which is the act of simply driving around Gotham. The default control scheme for the vehicle is cumbersome and counterintuitive to every driving game you’ve ever played prior to this. Thankfully, there’s an option to resort to using a secondary, more recognizable setup for the vehicle, but the catch is that that option isn’t explicitly presented in the options menu. So while this problem is technically fixable, I’d wager that many players still be stuck using the default scheme just based upon how muddled the process of altering it is.  Assuming you actually get around to using the secondary scheme, driving around the city can be quite enjoyable, but it still leaves a bit to be desired.  Many of the streets in Gotham feel a bit too narrow for the Batmobile, so you’ll often collide against the side of buildings whenever you turn onto another street, and there are few streets that allow the Batmobile to accelerate to its top speed for more than a couple of seconds.  Gliding around the city and using your grappling hook is still a far more preferable method to traverse the urban landscape, especially since Batman can now select his next grappling target while still being reeled in on his hook, allowing for a more fast-paced, instantaneous travel experience. While I appreciate how this addition makes traveling more efficient, it takes away a lot of the skill required to hone the grappling hook in Arkham City, where accuracy and timing were more predominant.  The vehicle’s other mode transforms it into a tank that you use to engage unmanned, remote-controlled drones.  Most of these encounters boil down to shooting at enemy drones while constantly dodging their line of fire by quickly thrusting left or right. Continually obliterating these enemy drones progressively builds up a meter in the corner of the screen, which, once filled, allows your tank to unleash a barrage of missiles upon your enemies. Now, there’s nothing inherently wrong or broken with these tank battles, but they lack any real opportunities to approach them in different ways like the aforementioned sequences, both of which have had three games to be refined to perfection. Many of its sections in the game require you to sneak around behind a beefed-up tank and hit it in its weak spot, drive away, and then repeat the same attack. I firmly believe that the Batmobile should've been relegated as a transportation option only, or perhaps having side missions devoted to it, but certainly not mandatory for around 40% of main story missions. If the developers so desperately wanted it to be included in the primary missions, then those missions should’ve been open-ended to the point whereplayer can complete them in several different ways.  The other major issue I have with this game in terms of its game design is the absence of any substantial boss fights. Granted, there is one exception that takes place around halfway through the game, where Batman fights alongside Robin to defeat a formidable, muscle-bound African-American boxer. The fight sequence is one of the few highlights of the game because it takes advantage of the best aspects of the series. However, as good as the fight is, it doesn’t suffice when it lasts for ten minutes at most and it takes roughly 15 hours to complete the game. Almost every other boss fight in the game is vehicular, involving the same repetitive techniques you employ during each tank fight. This problem wouldn’t upset me so much if the boss fights in the previous games hadn’t been so excellent.  The game even rubs salt in the wound by featuring Deathstroke, with whom Batman had engaged in a momentous clash in Arkham Origins, only to have him fight Batman in yet another generic tank battle before getting his lights punched out instantly as soon as he steps foot outside his tank.  There are a bevy of side missions at your disposal, most of which I haven’t bothered to delve into just yet. I attempted to complete a few Riddler challenges, which, to my knowledge, only consist of driving the Batmobile around underground racetracks, which grew tiresome very quickly. Perhaps I’ll return to complete all of the side activities eventually, but from what I’ve experienced of them so far, they’re comparable to those featured in Arkham City.  The audiovisual presentation in this game is phenomenal on all fronts.  The Arkham games have always excelled in this department, but this game outclasses them by having better lighting, smoother animations, and far more activity occurring on screen at once.  This game joins, and even surpasses in some aspects, the ranks of The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt and Far Cry 4 as being one of the best-looking games ever made.  In terms of sound, everything you hear during gameplay is fine, and the voice acting for the most part is good. I was disappointed in the Arkham Knight’s voice because it made him appear less intelligent and too whiney, and Kevin Conroy at times sounds uninspired during certain scenes, lacking inflection and conviction in his voice.  I know that a lot of people feel nothing but contempt for Arkham Origins, but for me, this is by far the worst game of this now four-part series. While the game is gorgeous to behold, and its hand-to-hand and predatory segments are mechanically flawless, many of the villains and ideas in the story are mishandled, the tank combat is lackluster, and there are hardly any worthwhile boss encounters.  Don’t get me wrong, this is still a solid enough game, (although I wouldn’t recommend paying full price for it) but it’s ultimately just extremely disappointing to me as a follow-up to Arkham City, which I still consider to be one of the best games I’ve ever played.

I've had this game for several years and I've always put it off thinking I had to play the other two games in the series first. In the end I just decided I may as well play it and see what all of the fuss is about. I think that was a mistake. The orange objective marker gives you a general idea where you have to go but it's up to you on how to get there which would be fine if the levels weren't so confusing.  This is especially true when they throw in an optional objective with no indication which orange marker is the optional one. Most of the enemies were pretty dumb that always popped their head out of cover at the exact same place every time. Not even attempting to alter their patterns. You had this little cutscene first about how you'll be captured or something and then you are and are being exchanged. Bottom line, if you're using Windows 10, just go ahead and pass these up.

Whenever I buy an open-world RPG, I accept the risk that the $60 I spent will be wasted on a game I'll never play. Generally speaking, I quickly get bored with RPGs: the confusing 10-page character menus, the tedious herb-gathering or ore-mining, and the pointless side-quests. For that reason, I feared that Witcher 3 would collect dust on my shelf. But so far, the game is nearly impossible to stop playing. At the moment, I'm inclined to call it the first great RPG of the next generation consoles!

Graphics 9/10: Definitely nex-gen quality. Human faces are unique and detailed, a great improvement from games like Skyrim. The environment itself isn't as awe-inspiring as Skyrim, as it lacks mountains and feels more restrictive. However, it does well what it chooses to do. My only complaint is that sometimes the fields or forests are overwhelmingly bright and colorful. It's almost too much to take in.

Gameplay/Mechanics 8/10: I admit, Gerault is sometimes hard to control. My biggest issue is how easily he can fall over the sides of narrow bridges, stairs, etc. Many recent games make it impossible to fall to your death at such times, but Witcher doesn't. This isn't a huge problem, but its worth noting. Otherwise, the mechanics are pretty good, especially in combat (explained next).

Combat 9.5/10: The combat is exceptionally good. I like how it allows players to integrate parries, dodges, spells, and basic attacks into each combat situation. I also like how sword duels include swords clashing against swords. Unlike games like Assassin's Creed, where holding LT would block unlimited attacks from unlimited attackers, Witcher requires parries to be expertly timed. Sometimes, evading attacks is safer than parrying. This makes for a flexible and interactive combat experience.

Story and Acting 10/10: The story is compelling and interesting. In particular, the characters are interesting. Doug Cockle brings Gerault's character to life with his low, cynical-sounding voice and narration. This is refreshing after games like Shadow of Mordor, Assassin's Creed, and Destiny failed miserably to give personality to their lead characters. This game is still behind The Last of Us, but it's also many times longer than that game.

column6: Toy Soldiers: War Chest - Hall Of Fame Edition (Playstation 4) Brand new
column14:
Looks can be deceiving. Sometimes something that looks great on the surface doesn't stay that way deeper down. Toy Soldiers: Hall of Fame War Chest Edition is a decently fun continuation of the Toy Soldiers series that ends up making itself shallower in some areas while trying to make itself deeper. There is a single player campaign, multiplayer and co-op modes, weekly “wars” and multiple hero armies to choose from. While all the variety makes the game broad, it doesn’t make it very deep in the process.

The game’s campaign takes place over a series of varied environments set to replicate various genres of toys. You start out with the Kaiser’s army, which will be familiar to anyone who played the original Toy Soldiers. Through the next couple of missions you are able to unlock the Ghost army, which is a futuristic sci-fi oriented guerilla army, a Rainbow Bright army which is, well, fairies and gummy bears and Rainbow Bright-esque units, and finally the Dark Lord’s army which is a fantasy themed army. Each hero comes with a unique army type around the theme of the hero as listed above. There are additional heroes available for purchase, GI Joe, Cobra (from GI Joe), He-Man and Ezio from Assassin’s Creed. The four purchasable heroes have armies made of toys from their respective themes. The campaign itself has a good variety in the different environments you face. From WWI trenched battlefields to bright colorful game boards to asteroid mining bases you end up fighting the four original heroes in their own themes. There are three survival battlefields to fight each of the purchasable heroes (GI Joe and Cobra are combined) where you fight for as long as possible until overrun.

Gameplay is the same as the previous games. Build towers to defend a toy box from an onslaught of enemies coming in waves. Through the game as you level up your heroes you gain blind boxes, as the game calls them, that unlock upgrades or you can purchase the upgrades for towers with coins you earn throughout the game. Upgrades are specific to the towers for that hero. The coins are given out generously enough that over the course of doing the campaign with a hero I easily unlocked every upgrade for Cobra and had a pile of coins to spare. If you control towers during the game and rack up kills with them you’re able to unlock a single use powerful hero or barrage to aid you when called upon. Once used you can earn the hero or barrage again by controlling towers and killing enemies. You can repeat that cycle as many times as you wish over the course of a match.

While there is a good amount of variety, a lot of it becomes superficial as the game goes on. There are a variety of hero armies, but they all basically play the same. There’s an anti-infantry tower, anti-armor tower, anti-air tower and an artillery tower. They look different and have some variation in cost and power, but each hero army has the same four basic towers that operate the same as the other hero armies. The campaign is the same no matter which hero army you use, and all the upgrades you unlock for the towers operate basically the same. The armies you fight in the campaign have a light infantry unit, heavy infantry unit, light armor unit, heavy armor unit, light air and heavy air. They may look different and act a little different but the basic concepts remain the same. While on the surface there is a lot of variety, and through the first games you play there will feel like a lot of variety, as the game goes on it becomes more of the same with different skins. It can also be annoying because you level up each hero separately and each tower upgrade for each hero army separately. So while my Cobra towers were beefed up, my Kaiser’s army towers were all base level after completing the campaign and a few other matches.

Stylistically the game looks good. On a technical level it won’t blow you away but it’s not a full priced game and if you’ve played theprevious Toy Soldier games you’ll know basically what to expect. Style over technical. The sound is decent. No real dialogue but the towers sound good and there are snipits of dialogue from the people manning the towers.

I went into Toy Soldiers: Hall of Fame War Chest Edition expecting about what I got out of the original two Toy Soldier games. A solid campaign that I would play through once, maybe twice and then just kind of walk away from it. And that’s basically what I got. I didn’t play through it twice like I did with Toy Soldiers Cold War, but it was decently fun, if a bit repetitive the first time through. I never felt the game’s battles were as deep as the previous two games. There weren’t as many towers and I felt like, while there was a good variety in the scenery and armies you fought, the levels didn’t feel as well developed. Perhaps that’s just me.

In the case of Toy Soldiers War Chest Hall of Fame Edition the appeal in the first couple of matches doesn't carry on deeper into the game. Things looks great on the surface, but don't necessarily evolve or improve as the game goes on. There is a ton of content in the game, if you like do the same thing over and over for various heroes. Some people will like to do that. I’ve reached NG++++ on Dark Souls 2, so obviously I’m not opposed to repeatedly playing something if the game is right, which this will be for some people. I would say for the majority of people this would be a better rent than buy. After playing the game I would probably put it at a $20 price point value to buy if I hadn't already played the game. It doesn't feel like a full priced game. I beat the campaign in an evening and didn’t really feel any need to go back. But if you get into the game and want to earn all the platinum medals and level up all the heroes there’s a lot of content.

column13: Greatly improved after disastrous launch; no subscription fee a plus
column14: Plagued with bugs at launch last year, the massive multiplayer online role-playing game (MMORPG) Elder Scrolls Online is now much improved.  It also had its $15-a-month subscription fee removed earlier this year, making it one of the most-played MMORPGs right now.  Set in the Elder Scrolls universe, ESO offers much more territories to travel than earlier ES games: you can visit much of Tamriel, including parts of Skyrim and Cyrodiil, and beyond.  ESO offers a good mix of solo-questing, group-questing, combat, crafting, guild participation, and storytelling.  Those who played earlier ES games will not lose the single-player "feel" in the gameplay, while still being able to participate in group plays that MMORPGs are made for.  There are, of course, many differences between ESO and earlier ES games.  You need constant Internet connection to play ESO, of course, and you need an account with Bethesda, the publisher.  As in other MMORPGs, you see other online players in the game in places accessible to all, but there are areas "instanced" only to you.  Everything in ESO happens in real time: you cannot save and load game, or pause during action.  Many enemies respawn a certain time after being killed, so other online players can fight them.  Your inventory is limited to 60 items at the start; you can buy additional slots later; there is no weight associated with each item.  You cannot put items in containers as in earlier ES games; you can only put them in your inventory or your "bank account" (which is also limited to 60 items at the start).  There are only about 20 ingredients each for alchemy, enchanting, food, and drink, unlike Skyrim that has over 100 of each.  Regarding quick travel, you can only quick-travel to "waypoints" located throughout Tamriel, and you pay a fee if your departure point is not a waypoint.  Significantly, ESO doesn't let you switch weapons during combat, unless when you reach Level 15, which will give you a secondary weapon slot.  One big difference compared to earlier ES games is that you have a large amount of magical attacks at your disposal even if you are not a mage or at low levels.  EVERY WEAPON TYPE is associated with a whole slew of magical attacks, called "active abilities" here.  Bows have a set of attacks, 2-handed weapons have a set, as do dual-wield weapons, destruction staves, and one-handed weapons with shields.  In addition, active abilities are also given to your class, your race, and the guilds you have joined.  Some of these abilities use magicka, and some use stamina.  Some of these attacks are fairly powerful as well, even at low levels, so you cannot ignore their use.  That makes it imperative even for non-mage characters to have an ample amount of magicka and stamina.  You up either your health, magicka, or stamina by one point every time you level up.  There are also "treasure maps" throughout Tamriel, some you can find in your travels, and some you start with if you buy some of the special editions of ESO, such as "Explorers' Pack" or "Imperial Edition".  A treasure map is a crudely drawn picture of a treasure chest's location.  Such maps are quite numerous in the game.  Another interesting feature of ESO are "dolmen battles".  A dolmen is a portal that occasionally pours out an army of daedric creatures, sort of like Oblivion Gates in "Elder Scrolls IV: Oblivion".  There are many dolmens throughout Tamriel.  Fighting in dolmen battles gives you experience points, achievements, and loot.  Looting dead enemies is a little different in ESO in that if you killed the enemy more "efficiently", you might get better loot.  Same thing happens in dolmen battles: the player who performed most efficiently in the battle gets the most loot.  Leveling up is handled in similar fashion as in Skyrim and Oblivion: you gain experience points by completing quests and also by performing tasks that yield experience for such tasks.  E.g. using a bow grants you experience for your Bow skill, crafting an iron weapon gives you Blacksmith skill experience, etc.  ESO also has "crafting writs", where you craft a specified amount of weapons and armor to get rewards and experience.  Rewards can be quite significant for such tasks so don't pass them up.  One popular quest line in Skyrim is Dark Brotherhood, which unfortunately is not in ESO.  A recent announcement by Bethesda, however, hinted that Dark Brotherhood would be added later on.  Thieves Guild also doesn't seem to be in ESO.  But there are "fences" who buy your stolen goods and clear your bounty.  You cannot buy homes in ESO the way you do in earlier ES games.  About the only things you need to buy are horses and extra inventory slots, and both are expensive.  You can buy either the 2014 launch version of ESO or the renamed "Tamriel Unlimited" edition from 2015, provided you obtain an unused activation code.  Whether you install from discs or online, the game will automatically download all the latest patches (many gigabytes in total) before you can start the game.

I am a bit of an audiophile and have been into the pro audio side of things for a good many years and built a set of my own speakers, so it may be worth mentioning that I do have high expectations for sound quality. I bought these for office use (90% music and 10% phone calls). I wanted something wireless, over-the-ear style that I could wear all day, and with an extendible mic and mute button. After reviewing the comments on these, I figured I'd give it a shot, but unfortunately, I was quite disappointed - even for the price point.

I would be using these for 90% music and 10% phone calls, so I wanted something with good sound quality. I've scrolled through all of the 3 eq settings on these and none of them sound very good at all. It sounds hollow all over the spectrum. I like a very well balanced speaker and am certain not a fan of 'bass thumping', but the bass on these is just ok at best. It's rather muddy and lackluster. It's there, but it just feels lazy. The mid range follows the same pattern. It just sounds lifeless and stressed. Similar story with the treble - it lacks presence and doesn't draw you into the musical experience. To add to the frustration, there is always a hum regardless of the volume levels you set it at. I do know about proper gain structure, but setting up the gain structure properly did nothing to help the hum - it's just always there and always comes through between songs or during quiet parts and is really distracting. It doesn't really get very loud either if that's your thing - it runs out of steam long before my $10 earbuds would even break a sweat.

I haven't found these to be terribly comfortable although they are ok I guess given that I haven't used them for extended periods. Their physical size it a bit large, but I haven't felt as though they're about to fall off.

The range is pretty good and I can walk around the office and my team's section without it breaking up at all, but the usb plug is abouttwice the size of an old school usb stick when they first came out and also plugs into your computer's headphone jack.

In general, they're kinda cool with the color changing feature and all and the range is good, but the sound quality just kills it for me. I've gone back to my old setup of my $10 ear buds and a cheapo headset for calls and this is now collecting dust in my drawer.

column13: A pretty good mech warrior type FPS that falls short in some key areas
column14:
This is a Saturn only release that provides a pretty fun intergalactic romp against an untrustworthy alien race called the Ghen. This is basically a first person shooter more akin to the likes of Mech Warrior than it is Doom or Duke Nukem. You control a mech suit fully loaded with an arsenal of weapons, including blasters w/unlimited ammo, rockets, homing missiles, mines and even a decoy to fool your enemy. Although they look dated today, the graphics were probably cutting edge for its time (1995) and feature full 360° controls, detailed enemies and solid effects. The music and sound effects are a strong point of this title. When enemies approach, the music picks up pace and intensity, creating a more realistic and powerful enemy encounter. There are also nifty full motion video cut scenes with live actors between each mission. While they feature some cheesy acting, it is still cool and almost like watching a movie to tell the story of the game.

Two major complaints about Ghen War are the controls and the lives/continue system, or lack there of. Firstly, although there are lots of different weapons and maneuvers available, it is cumbersome using them all on a control pad. For example, you have to scroll through all of the weapons with one button, so during the heat of battle, you have to take your eyes off of the enemy and watch the weapon box until you land upon your weapon of choice. That's just not conducive to real time combat! I've found myself getting hit numerous times while trying to switch weapons and navigate the clunky controls. Combine that with slow and cumbersome movement of your mech, and it can be a recipe for disaster during heavy battle. This might not be as bad if you had a fair amount of lives or continues, but you don't. Once you lose all of your lives, you are forced back to the beginning of the entire game and it replaces your existing save! It's like starting all over. As if that weren't bad enough, if you have to leave a mission for whatever reason, you lose a life. You must complete the current mission and allow the game to auto-save your progress to avoid this. There is just no reason for this kind of nonsense and it really detracted from what could have been a pretty good game.

Regarding the controls, Ghen War probably would play much better on a PC, where you could assign weapons to specific keys and use a mouse/keyboard for movement. With the control pad and they way they laid out the controls, it is a bit awkward and especially bad for real time combat. column13: Tales of Graces f - PlayStation 3 - Review by TheAirKing
column14: Tales of Graces f is a spectacular game on PlayStation 3, which continues to provide more and more enjoyment as one plays through the lives of main protagonist Asbel and his companions, and sees their growth from children to heroes.    Before providing more details on the pleasure of playing the game, one must first review the product and the packaging itself. The front cover is a wonderful piece of art that can only help to separate this game from the many soulless covers used for entertainment products in the modern market place. Once inside, the buyer will find a colorful disk and an instruction booklet featuring another terrific illustration of the main cast of characters. Instruction booklets are no longer common place for video games, and to find one with a separate artwork from the main cover is even more rare, making a nice additional treat to the product's artistic packaging. As can be told by the cover, Tales of Graces f is rated Teen, but parents shouldn't be worried, there is no blood and very little language. It gains it's Teen rating from mature themes, and some suggestive jokes.    As for story, players will be treated to a tale of friendship, and the struggles of growing up together in the political landscape of three conflicting nations. At first the political overtones are light and seem to matter very little, but they become more complex and intriguing, as do the characters the player is following. Despite this, the game is humorous throughout, and almost all of the main cast display a sense of sarcasm, even the seemingly gruff Malik. Those who enjoy anime, will derive extra fun from the game's magically animated cinematic scenes and skits. Fans hoping for a Japanese voice over track to be included with this localization will be sadly disappointed, but can also take heart in the fact that the English voice overs are for the most part extremely well done, especially for the main characters. Asbel, Cheria, Sophie, Pascal, Hubert, Richard, and Malikare all paired with actors who fit their appearance and emotions, both as children and adults. As the long and epic tale progresses, one can expect twists, betrayals, deaths, and a budding romance between Asbel and Cheria that continues to develop throughout the story from the time they are children.    Gameplay consists of exploring and battling, and fans of the "Tales of" series will find a refinement of what has come before. Newcomers can expect to be introduced to smooth and fast paced battles; a staple of the long running franchise. The game starts our heroes off as children and gives important backstory, while also serving as a tutorial to teach new players how to fight enemies. Up to four players can join together to fend off foes. Tales of Graces f boasts clean and crisp graphics, and the colorful settings accentuate the anime styled backdrop. There are people to talk to, puzzles to solve, treasures to find, and one must always be on the lookout for watchable hidden skits that provide extra character moments and depth.    All in all, Tales of Graces f has tons of content to offer long time fans, while making for a great entry point for newcomers. Tales of Graces f is a classic in both its genre and the video gaming scene at large.

column13: Why Did We Wait So Long?
column14:
Note: I bought the same Wii U bundle used from another vendor so no there's "confirmed purchase" next to my review.

I've played (console) videogames since 1985 when I was, coincidentally, 5.

I started off with an NES, then moved on to an SNES, then Genesis, then (after a gap) a PS2, PS3, XBox 360 with a Kinect (a nod to and an attempt to find games for our then-young children), and now PS4.
The last is down in the bedroom as a disc/streaming/gaming machine. The PS3 is up in the family TV room as, honestly at this point, a disc/Netflix/Amazon player and Minecraft console for our now-slightly-older kids, and the 360's about to be moved into a workout area for the Kinect fitness games.
I'd tried to drag my kids along into gaming (SEE? LITTLE BIG PLANET IS GREAT! PLAY IT!), but Minecraft's the only one that's stuck.

Then I stopped by a local gaming store and bought a used Wii U, some controllers, Splatoon, MarioKart 8, and Super Smash Bros (the console came with Super Mario 3D). By that evening, we'd only gotten to MarioKart - we were having so much fun.
As I whipped around a corner and did a trick-jump as Yoshi, I realized that I was grinning from ear to ear.
Super Mario 3D was just as smile-inducing and filled with loads of nostalgia (for me, anyway - I had to explain to my kids why I thought some of the references and levels were funny) and Super Smash Bros...well, I just spent a bit too much money on a Samus amiibo (her nickname: Samawesome), our middle "earned" her Link by spontaneously changing out the tablecloth after she spilled something on it during breakfast, our eldest has a Zelda held in reserve awaiting an act of uncoerced chore doing, our youngest has a Pikachu chilling until she does something spectacular befitting a small child, and I have a Mega Man on order for my not-as-enthusiastic-about-games-but-with-fond-Mega-Man-II-memories husband. And we've been able to play all of these together - thank you, Nintendo, for keeping local co-op alive.
Splatoon, currently being test driven by our eldest after she did crafts with and made lunch for her little sisters (score), also seems like it'll be as colorfully raucous as the rest. I may even let my kids dip their toes into online play given that Nintendo (pretty sagely if they're trying to keep it family-friendly) developed it without voice chat.

No, it doesn't have the processing power of this gen's consoles, but I wouldn't want to play Witcher 3 on this.
It does what it does and it does it well - fun but friendly games, (mostly) local co-op, and a control system that gets you a bit more into the game without being unbearably awkward and buggy like just about everything that's been done so far with cameras and paired sensors.

Even after dropping every single dollar of a (smallish) equity payment we received after a sale on the system, enough controllers for our family of five, a few games, and a few amiibo, the only thing I regret is not jumping back into Nintendo's world sooner.-op alive.
